[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-rest-client/src/lib.rs] [Function: version_path_base()] [Path Traversal] Can an attacker bypass the trailing slash check by providing a version_path_base like 'v1/../../../etc/passwd/' to access arbitrary filesystem paths on the server through URL manipulation? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-rest-client/src/lib.rs] [Function: build_path()] [URL Injection] Does build_path() properly sanitize the path parameter, or can an attacker inject malicious URL components (e.g., '../admin/sensitive_data') to access unauthorized API endpoints? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-rest-client/src/lib.rs] [Function: build_path()] [SSRF Attack] Can an attacker manipulate the path parameter to include absolute URLs (e.g., 'http://internal-network/admin') causing the client to make requests to internal services, leading to Server-Side Request Forgery? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-rest-client/src/lib.rs] [Function: path_prefix_string()] [Information Disclosure] Does the error handling in path_prefix_string() that returns '<bad_base_url>' leak sensitive information about internal URL structures when URL join operations fail? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-rest-client/src/lib.rs] [Function: get_prover_url()] [Hardcoded Path] Is the hardcoded path 'keyless/prover/v0/prove' vulnerable to version downgrade attacks where an attacker forces the client to use an older, vulnerable version of the prover API? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-rest-client/src/lib.rs] [Function: get_pepper_url()] [Hardcoded Path] Can an attacker exploit the unwrap() call in get_pepper_url() to cause a panic if base_url is malformed, leading to denial of service of the REST client? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-rest-client/src/lib.rs] [Function: check_and_parse_bcs_response()] [Deserialization Attack] Does check_and_parse_bcs_response() validate BCS data length before deserialization, or can an attacker send extremely large BCS payloads causing memory exhaustion and OOM crashes? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-rest-client/src/lib.rs] [Function: get_block_by_height_bcs()] [Type Confusion] Can an attacker craft malicious BCS data that deserializes to a BcsBlock with inconsistent internal state (e.g., mismatched transaction count vs actual transactions), causing state corruption? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-rest-client/src/lib.rs] [Function: get_transactions_bcs()] [Integer Overflow] In get_transactions_bcs(), can an attacker specify a limit parameter that causes integer overflow when combined with start parameter, leading to out-of-bounds memory access during BCS deserialization? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-rest-client/src/lib.rs] [Function: view_bcs()] [Malicious Bytecode] Does view_bcs() validate the ViewFunction bytecode before sending it to the server, or can an attacker inject malicious Move bytecode that exploits deserialization vulnerabilities in the server? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-rest-client/src/lib.rs] [Function: get_account_resource_bcs()] [Resource Exhaustion] Can an attacker request BCS deserialization of extremely large account resources causing CPU exhaustion through quadratic-time deserialization attacks? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-rest-client/src/lib.rs] [Function: simulate_bcs()] [Transaction Replay] Does simulate_bcs() properly handle BCS-deserialized transaction data to prevent replay attacks where an attacker resubmits simulated transactions with modified gas parameters? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-rest-client/src/lib.rs] [Function: get_index_bcs()] [State Manipulation] Can an attacker manipulate IndexResponseBcs during BCS deserialization to return inconsistent chain_id, epoch, or ledger_version values, causing clients to operate on wrong chain state? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-rest-client/src/lib.rs] [Function: get_transaction_by_hash_bcs()] [Hash Collision] Does get_transaction_by_hash_bcs() properly validate that the returned transaction hash matches the requested hash after BCS deserialization, or can an attacker exploit hash collisions to return wrong transactions? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-rest-client/src/lib.rs] [Function: submit()] [Transaction Malleability] Does submit() verify the transaction signature before submission, or can an attacker modify transaction fields after signing but before BCS encoding, causing signature verification to pass but executing different logic? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-rest-client/src/lib.rs] [Function: submit_batch()] [Batch Ordering Attack] Can an attacker manipulate the ordering of transactions in submit_batch() to front-run legitimate transactions, causing financial loss through MEV (Maximal Extractable Value) attacks? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-rest-client/src/lib.rs] [Function: submit_and_wait()] [Race Condition] Is there a race condition between submit() and wait_for_signed_transaction() where an attacker can inject a conflicting transaction with the same sequence number, causing the wrong transaction to be confirmed? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-rest-client/src/lib.rs] [Function: submit_without_deserializing_response()] [Silent Failure] Does submit_without_deserializing_response() properly check for transaction submission errors, or can it silently fail leaving the user unaware that their transaction was rejected? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-rest-client/src/lib.rs] [Function: submit_bcs()] [Double Submission] Can an attacker exploit submit_bcs() to submit the same transaction multiple times by manipulating the response state, causing double-spending or replay attacks? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-rest-client/src/lib.rs] [Function: submit_batch_bcs()] [Partial Batch Failure] Does submit_batch_bcs() handle partial batch failures correctly, or can an attacker cause some transactions to fail silently while others succeed, leading to inconsistent state? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-rest-client/src/lib.rs] [Function: wait_for_transaction_by_hash_inner()] [Timeout Bypass] Can an attacker manipulate the server's timestamp_usecs to bypass expiration checks in wait_for_transaction_by_hash_inner(), causing the client to wait indefinitely for expired transactions? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-rest-client/src/lib.rs] [Function: wait_for_transaction_by_hash_inner()] [State Confusion] In the loop at line 768, can an attacker cause state confusion by returning alternating Pending and NotFound states, making the client incorrectly conclude a transaction expired when it actually succeeded? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-rest-client/src/lib.rs] [Function: wait_for_transaction_by_hash_inner()] [Clock Skew Attack] Does the comparison 'expiration_timestamp_secs <= state.timestamp_usecs / 1_000_000' at line 782 properly handle clock skew, or can an attacker exploit time differences between client and server to cause premature transaction expiration? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-rest-client/src/lib.rs] [Function: wait_for_transaction_by_hash_inner()] [Memory Leak] Does the infinite loop starting at line 768 properly clean up resources, or can an attacker cause memory leaks by forcing the client to wait for transactions that will never be committed? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-rest-client/src/lib.rs] [Function: wait_for_transaction()] [Transaction Substitution] Can an attacker substitute a different transaction with the same hash (via preimage attack) causing wait_for_transaction() to return success for a malicious transaction? (Critical)
